GENRE ANALYSIS

Moving to next section.

THE MISSION: GENRE

WHAT?Orient yourself to the story's style.
WHY?Genre sets our expectations for the plot.
PRO-TIPLook for clues like setting, atmosphere, and characters.
Discuss the strategy with students.

WHAT'S THE GENRE?

Ex 1: Before you read

classic horror story early science fiction
traditional fairy tale detective fiction
comedy and humor crime fiction
Discuss the strategy with students.

THE GENRE

Early Science Fiction / Classic Horror
Written in 1818, it combines elements of Gothic horror with scientific speculation (galvanism).

Frankenstein is considered one of the first science fiction novels because it uses scientific theory to create horror.
Discuss the answer with the class.

MARY SHELLEY

Ex 2: Scan the text

WHO?Mary Shelley (1797-1851)
WHERE?Near Geneva (with Lord Byron)
WHEN?Summer of 1816 (Stormy night)
HOW?Ghost story challenge -> Powerful vision

CHECK YOUR ANSWERS (Ex 3)

1. Promising, 2. How life begins, 3. Isolated, 4. A storm, 5. Fear
'I became more and more isolated... built a scientific machine... electricity from lightning...'

Victor's obsession leads him away from people and toward a dangerous experiment with nature.

THE STORY

Moving to next section.

FRANKENSTEIN

'On my first day at the university I met my teacher, Professor Waldman... He gave a wonderful talk... You will become great scientists... discover everything that you can.'

I worked very hard... discovered many things... built a scientific machine... My machine would help me answer the most important question of all: How does life begin?
Monitor student progress.

THE CREATION

'I had to watch bodies from the moment when they died... One day, the answer came to me... I could put life into a body.'

I built a very tall mast... catch lightning... send electricity down to my machine...

The creature opened its yellow eyes...
Monitor student progress.

COMPREHENSION

Moving to next section.

THE MISSION: RECALL

WHAT?Reconstruct the timeline of Victor's journey.
WHY?Cause and effect are key to understanding tragedy.
PRO-TIPLook for sequence markers like 'After two years' or 'Then one day'.
Discuss the strategy with students.

ORDER THE EVENTS (1/2)

Ex 5: Put in order (Items A-C)

aVictor works hard and creates an advanced machine.
bVictor is given his own laboratory. He builds a mast.
cVictor is scared. Wakes up with creature looking at him.
Discuss the strategy with students.

ORDER THE EVENTS (2/2)

Ex 5: Put in order (Items D-F)

dVictor learns about death, feels sure he knows secret of life.
eVictor meets Professor Waldman.
fVictor makes a body. Electricity brings it to life.
Discuss the strategy with students.

CORRECT ORDER (Ex 5)

1.e, 2.a, 3.d, 4.b, 5.f, 6.c
'On my first day... met Professor Waldman (e)... I worked very hard (a)... after two years I had discovered many things (d)... built a very tall mast (b)... lightning came (f)... my first feeling is fear (c).'

The story follows Victor's transition from a hopeful student to a terrified creator.
Discuss the answer with the class.

THE MISSION: DEEP SCAN

WHAT?Identify the narrator and the tone of the story.
WHY?Understanding 'Who' and 'When' reveals the character's perspective.
PRO-TIPNotice if the narrator seems happy or regretful about his past.
Discuss the strategy with students.

ANSWER THE QUESTIONS

Ex 6: Analysis

1. Who is the narrator of the story?
2. When is the story being related: at that time or at a later date?
3. What indications are there of things to come in the story?
Discuss the strategy with students.

ANALYSIS ANSWERS (Ex 6)

1. Victor Frankenstein, 2. Later date, 3. Clues of tragedy
'I did not know then that my work would destroy me... I was making a terrible mistake.'

The first-person retrospective narrator uses 'foreshadowing' to warn the reader of the coming disaster.
Discuss the answer with the class.

Illustrations emphasize the Gothic themes of isolation and the dangers of obsession.

LITERARY STRATEGY

Moving to next section.

THE MISSION: PROFILE

WHAT?Analyze Victor's personality flaws.
WHY?Characters aren't perfect; their mistakes drive the story.
PRO-TIPA flaw is a weakness that usually leads to a big mistake.
Discuss the strategy with students.

CHARACTER FLAWS

Why give characters flaws?

Make them realistic and believable.
Create conflict and drama.
Explain choices leading to tragedy.
Discuss the strategy with students.

VICTOR'S FLAWS (1/2)

Ex 8: Check the flaws Victor has

arrogant obsessive
indecisive reckless
Discuss the strategy with students.

VICTOR'S FLAWS (2/2)

Ex 8: Check the flaws Victor has

irresponsible unfocused
jealous
Discuss the strategy with students.

VICTOR'S FLAWS (Ex 8)

Obsessive, Irresponsible, Reckless
'I worked very hard and soon... realized I could learn to be a very good scientist... did not take one day's holiday during the next two years.'

His obsession leads him to ignore social boundaries and personal health, making him irresponsible.
Discuss the answer with the class.

THEMES

Ex 9: Central Themes

Dangerous and forbidden knowledge
Courage, nobility, and heroism
Morals and distinguishing right from wrong
The dangers of fame and fortune
Discuss the strategy with students.

KEY THEMES

Dangerous Knowledge & Morality
'My work would destroy me... I was making a terrible mistake.'

The story warns us that seeking power over life and death without responsibility leads to tragedy.
Discuss the answer with the class.
